_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at this facility 



Direct Fuels has a proactive approach to overall chemical safety at their facility.  The terminal manager, operators, and senior management have a strong commitment to safety and implementation of safe procedures. The facility maintains an Integrated Contingency Plan that complies with OSHA and EPA emergency response and release requirements which includes periodic safety training.



Facility operations and the regulated substance handled 



Direct Fuels' current operation involves separation of fuel mixture (e.g., mainly mixtures containing gasoline, diesel and/or jet fuel) back into useable gasoline and diesel that is distributed back into the fuel market. The most common mixture separated is pipeline transportation mixture or "transmix" which is the fuel interface that forms when finished fuels are sequentially sent down pipelines from upstream refineries to local fuel distribution terminals.  Direct Fuels is introducing new process equipment and associated process changes to reduce total sulfur in their existing diesel stream.  Hydrogen (regulated RMP substance) is needed in the reactions that reduce sulfur and will be stored on-site and metered to the process as it is needed.

    

General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps 



The facility complies with the following accidental release programs: OSHA PSM, EPA SPCC, EPA Emergency Action Plan, and OSHA Emergency Response.  The facility has coordinated the introduction new processes (including the presence of hydrogen) with the City of Fort Worth Fire Department, Fire Prevention Bureau.



Five-year accident history 



This facility has not had a reportable release of a RMP substance in the last 5 years.  No release of any substance in the last 5 years has caused serious harm to employees or off-property persons.



Emergency response program 



Direct Fuels emergency response program wil

l be coordinated with the City of Fort Worth Fire Department.  Direct Fuels has various on-site alarm systems and operational safeguards to alert personnel of dangerous situations and reduce the potential of releases of chemicals.  The equipment that stores and processes hydrogen will be maintained by trained compressed gas professionals.



Planned changes to improve safety



Direct Fuels will undergo on-site process safety management training with professionals experienced in the operation of the new process equipment. This includes initial start-up activities.
